Connect with Corina Email: cc2@ecs.soton.ac.uk Tel: +44 23 8059 3625 ORCID On this page About Research Publications Biography About Research Publications Biography About Dr Corina Cirstea is an Associate Professor in the Agents, Interaction and Complexity research group in the School of Electronics and Computer Science at the University of Southampton. Her main research is in the field of coalgebra and its applications to computer science, in particular its relationship to the areas of logic, automata, games and formal verification. Dr Cirstea currently leads the COVER project (COalgebraic foundations for quantitative VERification), funded by the Leverhulme Trust and joint with the University of Starthclyde. This project aims to build new foundations for quantitative verification, grounded in a coalgebraic modelling of systems, and aimed at expanding the scope of quantitative verification and improving its scalability. Moss, Victoria Noquez, Todd Schmid, Alexandra Silva & Ana Sokolova, 2024 DOI: 10.4230/LIPIcs.CSL.2025.30 Type: conference Using Kan extensions to motivate the design of a surprisingly effective unsupervised linear SVM on the occupancy dataset Matthew Pugh, Jo Grundy, Corina Cirstea & Nick Harris, 2024, Mathematical and Computational Applications, 29(5) DOI: 10.3390/mca29050074 Type: article Linear-time logics - a coalgebraic perspective Corina Cirstea, 2024, Logical Methods in Computer Science, 20(2), 13.1-13.55 DOI: 10.46298/lmcs-20(2:13)2024 Type: article Formal specification of actual trust in multiagent systems Michael Akintunde, Vahid Yazdanpanah, Asieh Fathabadi, Corina Cirstea, Mehdi Dastani & Luc Moreau, 2024 DOI: 10.3233/FAIA240179 Type: conference Coalgebraic CTL: fixpoint characterization and polynomial-time model checking Ryota Kojima, Corina Cirstea, Koko Muroya & Ichiro Hasuo, 2024 Type: conference Actual Trust in Multiagent Systems Michael Akintunde, Vahid Yazdanpanah, Asieh Salehi Fathabadi, Corina Cirstea, Mehdi Dastani & Luc Moreau, 2024 Type: conference Biography Dr Corina Cirstea holds a DPhil in Computation from the University of Oxford (2000) and was the holder of a Junior Research Fellowship in Computer Science at St. John's College Oxford (1999-2003) prior to joining the University of Southampton. Her research interests are in logic and models of computation, more specifically in coalgebras, their connection to modal logics, and their applications to automated verification.
